results.title: ‘Rust’ Armorer Has ‘No Idea’ How Live Rounds Got on Set, Lawyers Say
results.abstract: Hannah Gutierrez-Reed was in charge of firearms on the New Mexico film set where Alec Baldwin fatally shot a cinematographer with a gun that was not supposed to contain live ammunition.

multimedia.caption: The movie set in New Mexico where a cinematographer was shot and killed with a gun that the actor Alec Baldwin had been rehearsing with. The crew had said the gun was safe, but it turned out to be loaded with live ammunition.

results.title: A Filmmaking Life Gets a Sequel
results.abstract: Joanna Hogg is the rare director to be given the greenlight for a two-part drama about finding her own voice. She’s only been thinking about it since 1988.

multimedia.caption: Joanna Hogg said she initially planned to shoot both parts of “The Souvenir” at the same time because “there was a danger that if I just made the first one, I wouldn’t get the opportunity to make the second one.”

results.title: Sean Penn the Focus of N.L.R.B. Amid Comments on Hours and Food at Vaccine Site

results.title: David DePatie, Producer Behind the Pink Panther, Dies at 91
results.abstract: He and the animator Friz Freleng created the cool feline character he called “the James Bond of the animation world.” The character’s first cartoon won an Oscar.

multimedia.caption: The producer David DePatie and the animator Friz Freleng, the forces behind the cartoon character the Pink Panther, in 1963. From left: Mr. Freleng, Mr. DePatie, Mr. Panther, the producer Harold Mirisch and Blake Edwards, director of the movie “The Pink Panther,” which used the character in its title sequence.

The producer David DePatie and the animator Friz Freleng, the forces behind the cartoon character the Pink Panther, in 1963. From left: Mr. Freleng, Mr. DePatie, Mr. Panther, the producer Harold Mirisch and Blake Edwards, director of the movie “The Pink Panther,” which used the character in its title sequence.

The producer David DePatie and the animator Friz Freleng, the forces behind the cartoon character the Pink Panther, in 1963. From left: Mr. Freleng, Mr. DePatie, Mr. Panther, the producer Harold Mirisch and Blake Edwards, director of the movie “The Pink Panther,” which used the character in its title sequence.

The producer David DePatie and the animator Friz Freleng, the forces behind the cartoon character the Pink Panther, in 1963. From left: Mr. Freleng, Mr. DePatie, Mr. Panther, the producer Harold Mirisch and Blake Edwards, director of the movie “The Pink Panther,” which used the character in its title sequence.

The producer David DePatie and the animator Friz Freleng, the forces behind the cartoon character the Pink Panther, in 1963. From left: Mr. Freleng, Mr. DePatie, Mr. Panther, the producer Harold Mirisch and Blake Edwards, director of the movie “The Pink Panther,” which used the character in its title sequence.

results.title: The film’s armorer, Hannah Gutierrez-Reed, told a detective she had checked to make sure rounds were not ‘hot.’
results.abstract: When the crew took a break for lunch, the ammunition was left out on a cart on the set, Ms. Gutierrez-Reed said.
results.byline: By Julia Jacobs and Simon Romero
